title: Microscopy and Cell Size
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding microscopy techniques including magnification, resolution, and calculations. Students learn to distinguish between light and electron microscopy and calculate actual cell sizes.
learningIntentions: Students can calculate magnification and actual size using scale bars and the formula: Actual size = Image size ÷ Magnification.
Students can distinguish between resolution and magnification.
Students can select the appropriate microscope (light vs electron) for viewing specific cell structures.

engagementHook.title: Breaking the Light Barrier
engagementHook.content: Show beautiful LM image of Paramecium vs grainy TEM of bacterium. 'The colourful one looks better, but the grainy one actually shows more detail. Why can't our most powerful light microscopes see the structures inside cells clearly?' Demo: Two pens held together—when close to eye, look like one object. 'Resolution is the limit.'

keyConcepts.definition: The ability to distinguish two separate points as distinct. Limited by wavelength of light (~200 nm for light microscopes).
How much larger the image is than the actual object. Empty magnification (increasing size without resolution) shows blurry images.
Uses visible light and glass lenses. Max resolution ~200 nm. Can view living cells. Stains add contrast (iodine, methylene blue).
Uses electron beams. TEM (Transmission) shows internal structure; SEM (Scanning) shows 3D surface. Resolution ~0.2 nm. Requires dead, fixed specimens.
Actual size = measured image size ÷ magnification. Unit conversions: 1 mm = 1000 µm; 1 µm = 1000 nm.

misconceptions.misconception: Higher magnification always means better detail
misconceptions.correction: Show blurry vs sharp images. Without resolution, high magnification is just a bigger blur (empty magnification).
They use electrons, not photons. Requires vacuum (so specimens must be dead).

misconceptions.misconception: You can see ribosomes with a light microscope
misconceptions.correction: Ribosomes ~20–30 nm; light microscope limit ~200 nm. Need EM.

contentSections.title: Calculation 1 – Using Scale Bars
contentSections.content: Step-by-step worked example for calculating actual size using a scale bar.
contentSections.problem: A micrograph shows a bacterial cell. The scale bar represents 2 µm and measures 10 mm on the page. The cell image measures 25 mm. What is the actual length?
steps: Find the ratio: 10 mm on page = 2 µm actual
Calculate: 1 mm on page = 2/10 = 0.2 µm actual
Answer: The actual cell length is 5 µm (within prokaryotic range)
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why must we use the same units for calculation? (To cancel correctly.)

contentSections.title: Calculation 2 – Unit Conversions
contentSections.content: Converting between common units in microscopy.
contentSections.problem: A mitochondrion is 1 µm long. How many nm is this? How many mm?
steps: Conversion ladder: mm → µm → nm (each step ×1000)

contentSections.title: Light vs Electron Microscopy
contentSections.example: Viewing COVID-19: LM shows infected cells; EM shows viral particles.

contentSections.title: Specimen Preparation
contentSections.content: For EM: Fixation (preserves structure), dehydration (removes water), staining with heavy metals (adds contrast). For LM: Wet mounts, simple stains (iodine).
contentSections.example: Diagnosing viral infections—EM used to identify virus shape in early outbreaks.

multipleChoice.question: The maximum resolution of a compound light microscope is approximately:
multipleChoice.rationale: Tests the Abbe limit/basic specification. Light microscopes are limited by wavelength of visible light to about 200 nm resolution.

multipleChoice.question: If the magnification of a micrograph is ×400 and the image size is 20 mm, the actual size is:
multipleChoice.rationale: Tests formula manipulation and unit conversion. Actual size = Image size ÷ Magnification = 20mm ÷ 400 = 0.05mm = 50µm.

multipleChoice.question: Which structure requires an electron microscope to be seen?
multipleChoice.rationale: Tests size vs resolution limit. Ribosomes (~25 nm) are smaller than the 200 nm limit of light microscopes. Nucleus, chloroplasts and cell walls are visible with LM.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between magnification and resolution. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Magnification is the degree of enlargement of the image
1 mark: Resolution is the ability to distinguish two separate points as distinct/level of detail
shortAnswer.commonError: Defining resolution as 'how big it looks.'

shortAnswer.question: A student views a cell using a ×40 objective lens and a ×10 eyepiece. The field of view at this magnification is 0.4 mm. Calculate the actual width of a cell that takes up half the field of view. Show your working. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Correct calculation of actual size (0.2 mm or 200 µm)
1 mark: Correct working shown (0.4 mm ÷ 2, or total mag = 400× then calculation)

definitions: Resolution = ability to distinguish detail; limited by wavelength of light (~200 nm for LM).
Magnification = how much bigger the image is than the object.
Light microscopes: use light, max resolution 200 nm, can view living cells.
Electron microscopes: use electrons, resolution ~0.2 nm, specimens must be dead.
keyPoints: Formula: Actual size = Image size ÷ Magnification
Empty magnification = bigger but not clearer (no resolution)
Ribosomes need EM (< 200 nm); nucleus visible with LM

shortAnswer: Magnification refers to how much larger the image is compared to the actual object, calculated as image size divided by actual size. Resolution is the ability to distinguish two separate points as distinct objects, which determines the level of detail visible.
Working: Total magnification = 40 × 10 = 400×. Cell takes up half the field of view = 0.4 mm ÷ 2 = 0.2 mm. Converting to µm: 0.2 mm = 200 µm. Therefore, the actual cell width is 0.2 mm or 200 µm.
